title: Ticket #331: Code review patch from Cycle Computing for resource weights.
description:
See more details here: 1699 (backup) 1699 (public) (http://nmi.cs.wisc.edu/node/1699)

This is a patch that was contributed for 7.1 in October 2008. Our customers are actively interested in this functionality.

This patch adds support for having different slots "cost" different amounts against the group quota (right now every slot costs 1). In the config file for a startd, ResourceWeight is a ClassAd expression which evaluates to the weight or cost of the resource.

For example: 

ResourceWeight = ifthenelse(SlotID == 1, $(Slot1ResourceWeight), $(OtherSlotResourceWeight))
Slot1ResourceWeight = 10.0
OtherSlotResourceWeight = 1.2
GROUP_NAMES = group_a
GROUP_QUOTA_group_a = 15
remarks:
# 1 Submitted by danb on Tue, 2008-10-28 17:41.

Nice, Ian!

Without running your code, I can't tell if the following dprintf provides enough context or not: 

+ if(candidate->EvalFloat(ResourceWeightAttr.Value(), NULL,
+ ResourceWeight) == 0) {
+ dprintf(D_FULLDEBUG, "Can't get ResourceWeight; using 1.0\n";);

Is the negotiator log just going to have this message show up out of the blue, or will it be obvious which machine ad is responsible?

Also, is "ResourceWeight" a better name than "SlotWeight"?

-Dan

# 2 Submitted by Ian on Tue, 2008-10-28 23:35.

Dan,

I'm reworking this patch after discussing some issues with Todd, to make sure that we're fair within groups.

I'll take a look at the context of this message - in the tests I've performed I have D_ACCOUNTING on. It's a good idea to identify the candidate explicitly.

Todd suggested ResourceWeight but he might like SlotWeight.

Thanks for the suggestions.

-Ian

# 3 Submitted by Todd Tannenbaum on Wed, 2008-10-29 10:55.

SlotWeight is fine imho if folks like it better than ResourceWeight, I have no strong feelings.

The patch as it currently exists (attachment resource_weight.diff) cannot go into the code because it looks like it breaks fair-share amongst users within a specific group. This functionality is required and cannot be removed. But once we get this aspect cleaned up, it looks very nice.

At first blush it seems fair-share within a group can be restored (or at least as fair as spinning-pie allows) by totaling the ResourceWeight of all candidate startds, and then multiplying this sum by the priority ratio instead of just using the number of startds. Course if ResourceWeight is not defined, it should default to be 1.0, and so the summation of ResourceWeights should equal # of startds and all is like it was before.

Another less attractive (but maybe safer) option if folks see a problem with the above idea is a knob that tells Condor to either honor fair-share within a group, or honor ResourceWeights.

Any other comments / thoughts?

Thanks for the patch Ian!!!!!

# 4 Submitted by Ian on Thu, 2008-10-30 14:23.

I've reworked the patch to add two things: adding computation of total resource weight as Todd suggests, and a knob NEGOTIATOR_USE_RESOURCE_WEIGHTS that if set to false (the default) will do things exactly as they are done now (resource weights have no effect, almost exactly the same code path is followed).

The way this works is by having a separate accounting system. The existing system is unaltered; the new system works alongside it.

The limitation of this work right now is that the priority system still uses the old integer weights to calculate usage and priority; so a user using one slot with ResourceWeight = 2 will have the same priority as a user using a slot with ResourceWeight = 0.5. In other words, NEGOTIATOR_USE_RESOURCE_WEIGHTS only affects group quotas, not priorities. I think this is useful as is, and I'll work on extending this feature to priorities as well as time permits (and again, using a parallel implementation).

2009-Apr-08 13:38:13 by tannenba:
Note - this patch also adds a matchmaker diagnostic 'rejected for group quota'. Nice. :)

2009-Apr-08 15:21:12 by matt:
Quick thoughts...

Can the ResourceWeight reference attributes from a potential or current job?

A slot may have some amount of memory, but a job may know it'll only ever use half. The job may just happen to not be using all the memory (might be possible already with STARTD_JOB_EXPRS). The node and system policy may have exceptions for certain Owners.

Is there a reason this can't just be on all the time (avoid YAK, yet another knob)?

There is already a default for ResourceWeight of 1, should probably be Cpus, which will allow for removal of code in the accountant that checks Cpus to do a primitive form of this feature.

It could avoid multiple tests for NEGOTIATOR_USE_RESOURCE_WEIGHTS and duplicate code blocks (see "if(useResourceWeights)").

2009-Apr-08 15:25:57 by tannenba:
If resource weights are not being used, aka NEGOTIATOR_USE_RESOURCE_WEIGHTS is set to false, the patch should be more careful to not introduce significant additional CPU demand into the negotiation cycle.

For instance, looks like the v2 patch below always calls sumResourceWeights() even if resource weights are not desired. And this is a very CPU-demanding function (evaluation on every machine ad).

Also, re the lets try to not introduce more knobs rule, couldn't the NEGOTIATOR_USE_RESOURCE_WEIGHTS knob be set automatically and thus not have to be a knob at all? Maybe a simple algorithm of if no machine ads contains a resource weight attribute then in the code useResourceWeights=false else true.

2009-Apr-08 15:59:27 by matt:
Assuming sumResourceWeights() is conditional...

Is sumResourceWeights() even necessary? It ads an extra iteration over all the ads and doubles the number of times EvalFloat(ResourceWeight...) is done.

Re: Auto Knob - Sounds cool as long as it does not require another iteration over the ads.

2009-Apr-13 11:49:12 by alderman:
See the above copied comments (#3) for why the sumResourceWeights function is necessary; it's to ensure fair share within groups.

In terms of turning this feature on automatically or all the time, I'd think it's an OK direction to go in but maybe it would be worthwhile to get a better sense of the performance impact w.r.t. summing the weights, etc. by having it be a knob for now. It seems to me that it would be better to have a knob until we can show that there's no performance penalty to 1) sumResourceWeights or 2) look through all machine ads for a ResourceWeight attribute.

2009-Apr-17 11:10:57 by matt:
Re comment 3: The goal was to provide fair-share amongst users within a group. That could be achieved using an upfront sum, but doing so introduces another iteration over the startd ads making it less likely to be on by default, results in evaluation of the ResourceWeights attributes multiple times, and doesn't allow for the possibility of referencing job attributes within the ResourceWeight. Rephrased: Is it necessary to sum weights upfront?

Re the knob: The more I think about it the more an auto-knob is scary, especially if this feature is slow. Assuming it is slow and can't be on by default - debugging why negotiation gets slow as a side-effect of a machine specifying a ResourceWeight, ouch.

2009-Apr-17 11:25:24 by alderman:
Agreed about the knob.

Todd points out that fair-share within a group is essential. In order to divide up the pie fairly, we need to know the size of the pie. Right?

Do you see a way to retain fair share that but not sum the weights?

2009-Apr-17 11:46:50 by matt:
If you don't have any ideas on how it could be worked around let me know and I'll think about it too.

If you think it's a necessity that cannot be worked around maybe we shouldn't bother.

2009-Apr-17 12:06:51 by alderman:
I think we need to do some performance testing to determine whether there's a problem at all before we try to find a work-around.

2009-Apr-17 12:12:09 by matt:
By all means, but there is still the functionality component. I don't think you can sum the weights upfront and let them reference job ads. Is that functionality just not possible?

2009-Apr-17 12:23:54 by alderman:
That's an interesting question. The problem is that, if the resources cost differing amounts for different members of the group, the size of the per group pie will vary. So, we might be able to make the weights per group but not per user?

2009-Apr-17 12:52:15 by matt:
Off the top of my head, summing for groups is the same as summing for jobs. You may not know the exact size of the pie upfront. Though with groups you'd have a smaller set of possible pie sizes.

So, you can think of doing something more probabilistic as you go along to estimate the pie size and existing slices. However, maybe you don't even need fair-share across weights and just across # of slots is enough.

What's the goal of this feature - what do you expect it to give you overall, what's a concrete use?

Maybe fair-share across # of slots is enough, but the charge back will be different across slots, which will effect shares in the future.

2009-Apr-20 11:41:20 by tannenba:
I think the earlier we get this code into the developer series the earlier we will know the answers to some of the above performance issues (or non-issues?). Merged and pushed resource_weight_v4.diff attachment below into the master branch as commit [14512]. Will resolve this ticket, can create child defect tickets if required if problems are encountered. Thanks for the patch, Ian.
